ai-pli-tv-kd16:1.1.1_0: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:1.1.2_0: At this time the Buddha had not yet allowed dwellings.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:1.1.3_0: And the monks stayed here and there:

ai-pli-tv-kd16:1.1.5_0: Early in the morning, they would emerge
ai-pli-tv-kd16:1.1.6_0: from those places, pleasing in the way they entered and returned, in looking at and in looking away, in bending and stretching out their arms; their eyes were lowered and they were perfect in deportment.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:1.2.1_0: One morning a prominent merchant of Rājagaha was going to a park
ai-pli-tv-kd16:1.2.3_0: from those places, pleasing in the way they entered and returned, in looking at and in looking away, in bending and stretching out their arms; their eyes were lowered and they were perfect in deportment.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:1.2.5_0: The merchant approached those monks and said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:1.2.6_0: “Venerables, if I build dwellings, would you stay there?”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:1.2.8_0: “Well then, Sir, please ask the Buddha and tell me the outcome.”

ai-pli-tv-kd16:1.2.11_0: and told him what was happening.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:1.2.12_0: “Venerable Sir, a prominent merchant of Rājagaha wants to build dwellings.

ai-pli-tv-kd16:1.2.14_0: who gave a teaching and addressed the monks:

ai-pli-tv-kd16:1.3.4_0: Then, on a single day, that merchant built sixty dwellings.

ai-pli-tv-kd16:1.3.6_0: and told him what had happened,

ai-pli-tv-kd16:1.3.8_0: And the Buddha consented by remaining silent.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:1.3.9_0: Knowing that the Buddha had consented, he got up from his seat, bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with his right side toward him, and left.

ai-pli-tv-kd16:1.4.2_0: “Sir, it’s time. The meal is ready.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:1.4.3_0: After robing up, the Buddha took his bowl and robe and went to the house of that merchant, where he sat down on the prepared seat together with the Sangha of monks.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:1.4.4_0: That merchant personally served various kinds of fine food to the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha. When the Buddha had finished his meal and had washed his hands and bowl, the merchant sat down to one side

ai-pli-tv-kd16:1.4.6_0: “Sir, I’ve had these sixty dwellings built to make merit and for the purpose of going to heaven.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:1.4.8_0: “Well then, give those sixty dwellings to the Sangha everywhere, both present and future.”

ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.1.1_0: The householder Anāthapiṇḍika was the brother in law of a prominent merchant in Rājagaha.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.1.2_0: Anāthapiṇḍika went to Rājagaha on some business.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.1.3_0: that merchant had invited the Sangha headed by the Buddha for the meal on the following day.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.1.4_0: The merchant was telling his slaves and workers
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.1.5_0: “Listen, then, getting up early and then, and take rice porridge. Practice he for more than to the neighborhood.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.1.7_0: “When I’ve arrived before, this householder put down all his business to greet me.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.1.8_0: But this time he’s all over the place,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.1.9_0: ‘Well then, my good rising early and get up early to serve them with rice porridge. Then take back rice and porridge.’
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.1.10_0: Is he preparing for a marriage or a great sacrifice, or has he invited King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha together with the army for a meal tomorrow?”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.2.1_0: When the merchant was finished with telling his workers what to do, he went up to Anāthapiṇḍika, greeted him, and sat down.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.2.2_0: Anāthapiṇḍika then told him what he had observed
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.2.3_0: “Householder, when I’ve arrived before, you put down all his business to greet me.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.2.4_0: But now you’re all over the place,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.2.5_0: ‘Well then, my good rising early and get up early to serve them with rice porridge. Then take back rice and porridge.’
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.2.6_0: and asked him what was happening.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.2.7_0: The merchant replied, “I’m not preparing for a marriage, nor have I invited King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha together with the army.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.2.8_0: But I’m preparing for a great sacrifice.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.2.9_0: I have invited the Sangha headed by the Buddha for a meal tomorrow.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.2.18_0: Is it possible at this time to go and visit that Buddha, that fully awakened and perfected one?”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.2.19_0: “Now is the wrong time to visit the Buddha.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.2.20_0: Tomorrow will be the right time.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.2.21_0: Because he lay down thinking of the Buddha—
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.2.22_0: “Tomorrow I will go and visit that Buddha, that fully awakened and perfected one!”—
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.2.23_0: he got up three times during the night thinking it was light.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.3.1_0: Then he approached the Sivaka Gate,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.3.2_0: and non-human beings opened it for him.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.3.3_0: Then, as he was leaving town, the light disappeared and it was dark. He was paralyzed with fear, with goosebumps all over,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.3.4_0: and he wanted to turn back.

ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.3.13_0: Going forward is better for you than going back.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.3.14_0: The light returned, the darkness disappeared,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.3.18_0: the light disappeared and he was paralyzed with fear,

ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.3.28_0: And on both occasions the light returned, the darkness disappeared, and his fear subsided.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.4.1_0: Anāthapiṇḍika then went to the Sītavana, the Cool Grove.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.4.2_0: Just then the Buddha was walking back and forth outside, having got up early in the morning.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.4.3_0: He saw Anāthapiṇḍika coming off in the distance.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.4.4_0: So he stepped down from the walking path, sat down on the seat spread out,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.4.7_0: Because he lay down thinking of the Buddha—

ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.4.10_0: “Sir, I hope the Buddha sleeps well?”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.4.13_0: Who’s not soiled among worldly pleasures,

ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.5.2_0: a talk on giving, ethical conduct, and heaven. He explained the drawbacks of sensual pleasures, so sordid and corrupt, and the benefit of renunciation.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.5.3_0: When the Buddha knew that his mind was ready, supple, without hindrances, joyful, and confident, he revealed the teaching unique to the Buddhas:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.5.5_0: Just as a clean and stainless cloth takes the dye properly,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.5.6_0: so too, while he was sitting right there, Anāthapiṇḍika experienced the stainless vision of the Truth:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.5.7_0: “Anything that has a beginning has an end.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.5.8_0: He had seen the Truth, had reached, understood, and penetrated it; he had gone beyond doubt and uncertainty, had attained to confidence, and had become independent of others in the Teacher’s instruction. He then said to the Buddha,

ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.5.11_0: those with eyes might see what’s there—
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.5.12_0: just so has the Buddha made the Teaching clear in many ways.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.5.13_0: I take refuge in the Buddha, in the Teaching, and in the Sangha of monks.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.5.14_0: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.5.15_0: Sir, please accept a meal from me tomorrow together with the Sangha of monks.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.5.16_0: And the Buddha consented by remaining silent.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.5.17_0: Knowing that the Buddha had consented, Anāthapiṇḍika got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.

ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.7.1_0: The following morning, in that prominent merchant’s house, Anāthapiṇḍika had various kinds of fine food prepared. He then had the Buddha informed
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.7.2_0: “Sir, it’s time. The meal is ready.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.7.3_0: After robing up, the Buddha took his bowl and robe and went to the house of that merchant, where he sat down on the prepared seat together with the Sangha of monks.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.7.4_0: Anāthapiṇḍika then personally served the various kinds of fine food to the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha. When the Buddha had finished his meal and had washed his hands and bowl, Anāthapiṇḍika sat down to one side
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.7.6_0: “Sir, please spend the rainy-season residence at Sāvatthī together with the Sangha of monks.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.7.7_0: “The Buddha delights in empty dwellings, householder.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.7.9_0: Then, after instructing, inspiring, and gladdening him with a teaching, the Buddha got up from his seat and left.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.8.1_0: After finishing his business in Rājagaha,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.8.3_0: Now at that time Anāthapiṇḍika had many friends and acquaintances who listened to him. On his way to Sāvatthī
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.8.4_0: he told people to make monasteries, to build dwellings, and to prepare offerings:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.8.6_0: He’s been invited by me and will be traveling this way.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.8.7_0: And those people did as Anāthapiṇḍika had urged them to do.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.8.8_0: After arriving at Sāvatthī, Anāthapiṇḍika searched all around town for a place for the Buddha to stay, thinking,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.8.10_0: that’s neither too far from the village nor too close, that has good access roads, that’s easily accessible for people who seek him, that has few people during the day and is quiet at night, that’s free from chatter and offers solitude, that’s away from human habitation and suitable for seclusion?”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.9.1_0: Anāthapiṇḍika saw that Prince Jeta’s park
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.9.3_0: He then went to Prince Jeta and said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.9.4_0: “Sir, give me your park to make a monastery.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.9.5_0: “I won’t give it even if you cover the park with ten million coins.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.9.8_0: They then asked judges to decide on the matter.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.9.10_0: “Sir, since you gave a price, the park is sold.”

ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.10.15_0: And he granted that area to Prince Jeta.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.10.16_0: Prince Jeta then had a gateway built at that place.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:4.10.17_0: Anāthapiṇḍika had dwellings build in the Jeta Grove, and precincts, gateways, assembly halls, water-boiling sheds, food-storage huts, restrooms, walking-paths, indoor walking-paths, wells, well houses, saunas, sauna sheds, ponds, and roof-covers.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.1.0_0: Putting in charge of building work
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.1.1_0: After staying at Rājagaha for as long as he liked, the Buddha set out wandering toward Vesālī.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.1.2_0: When he eventually arrived at Vesālī,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.1.3_0: he stayed in the hall with the peaked roof in the Great Wood.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.1.4_0: At that time people were doing careful building work.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.1.5_0: And the monks who supervised the building work were respectfully supported with robes, almsfood, dwellings, and medicines.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.1.6_0: Then a certain poor tailor thought,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.1.7_0: “This must be an important matter, since these people do such careful building work.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.1.8_0: I too should do building work.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.1.9_0: He then made a mixture of mud, made bricks out of it, and built a wall.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.1.10_0: But because of his lack of skill, the wall was not straight and it fell down.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.1.12_0: and a third time the same thing happened.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.1.13_0: But because of his lack of skill, the wall was not straight and it fell down.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.2.1_0: He then complained and criticized the monks,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.2.2_0: “These Sakyan ascetics teach and instruct only those who give them robes, almsfood, dwellings, and medicines. They only supervise their building work.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.2.4_0: nobody teaches, instructs, or supervises me.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.2.5_0: The monks heard the complaints of that poor tailor.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.2.7_0: who gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.2.8_0: “You should put a monk in charge of the building work.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.2.9_0: The monk in charge of building work should make an effort
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.2.10_0: to complete the dwellings as quickly as possible,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.2.11_0: and he should repair what is broken or damaged.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.3.1_0: And he is to be put in charge like this.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.3.2_0: First you should ask a monk, and then a competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.3.3_0: ‘Sir, let the Saṅgha listen to me.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.3.4_0: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, the Sangha should put monk so-and-so in charge of the building work relating to the dwelling of householder so-and-so.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.3.6_0: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.3.7_0: The Sangha puts monk so-and-so in charge of the building work relating to the dwelling of householder so-and-so.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.3.8_0: Any monk who approves of putting monk so-and-so in charge of that building work should remain silent.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.3.9_0: Any monk who doesn’t approves should speak up.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.3.10_0: The Sangha has put monk so-and-so in charge of the building work relating to the dwelling of householder so-and-so.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:5.3.11_0: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.1.0_0: The instruction on the best seat, etc.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.1.1_0: When the Buddha had stayed at Vesālī for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Sāvatthī.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.1.2_0: On that occasion the monks who were the pupils of the monks from the group of six went ahead of the Sangha headed by the Buddha and took possession of dwellings and beds, thinking,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.1.3_0: “This is our preceptor; this will be our preceptor for our teacher.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.1.4_0: Venerable Sāriputta followed behind the Sangha. Being unable to get a bed—the dwellings and beds having all been taken—he sat down at the foot of a tree.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.1.5_0: Then, after rising early in the morning, the Buddha cleared his throat.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.1.6_0: Sāriputta also gave him his throat.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.2.1_0: Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.2.2_0: “Is it true, monks, that the monks who are the pupils of the monks from the group of six did this?”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.2.3_0: This will be your preceptor for our teachers. This will be yours?”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.2.7_0: this will be your teacher; this will be your teacher.’
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.2.8_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...” ...
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.2.10_0: and after giving a teaching he addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.2.11_0: “Monks, who deserves the best seat, the best water, and the best almsfood?”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.2.13_0: “Those who have gone forth from an aristocratic family deserve the best seat, water, and almsfood.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.2.15_0: “Those who have gone forth from an brahmin family deserve the best seat, water, and almsfood.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.2.17_0: “Those who have gone forth from an householder family deserve the best seat, water, and almsfood.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.2.19_0: Or, “The experts on the discourses deserve the best seat, water, and almsfood.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.2.21_0: Or, “The experts on the Monastic Law deserve the best seat, water, and almsfood.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.2.23_0: Or, “The expounders of the Teaching deserve the best seat, water, and almsfood.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.2.25_0: Or, “Those who obtain the first absorption deserve the best seat, water, and almsfood.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.2.27_0: Or, “Those who obtain the second absorption deserve the best seat, water, and almsfood.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.2.29_0: Or, “Those who obtain the third absorption deserve the best seat, water, and almsfood.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.2.31_0: Or, “Those who obtain the fourth absorption deserve the best seat, water, and almsfood.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.2.33_0: Or, “The stream-enterers deserve the best seat, water, and almsfood.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.2.35_0: Or, “The once-returners deserve the best seat, water, and almsfood.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.2.36_0: Or, “The nonreturners deserve the best seat, water, and almsfood.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.2.37_0: Or, “The perfected ones deserve the best seat, water, and almsfood.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.2.39_0: Or, “Those who have attained the three true insights deserve the best seat, water, and almsfood.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.2.41_0: Or, “Those who have attained the six direct knowledges deserve the best seat, water, and almsfood.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.3.1_0: When the message had been delivered, the Buddha said to the monks,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.3.2.1_0: “Once upon a time, mendicants, there was a great banyan tree on the slopes of the Himalayas.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.3.4_0: a partridge, a monkey, and an elephant.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.3.5_0: They were disrespectful, undeferential, and rude toward one another.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.3.7_0: ‘If only we knew which one of us was the oldest. We would honor, respect, and esteem him, and we would wait for his instructions.’
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.3.8_0: The partridge and the monkey then asked the elephant,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.3.9_0: ‘Well, my friend, what are you remember?’
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.3.10_0: ‘When I was a young, I stepped over this banyan tree, keeping it between my thighs, and the top shoots touched my belly.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.3.11_0: These are the traditions of the ancient.’
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.3.12_0: The partridge and the elephant asked the monkey,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.3.13_0: ‘Well, my friend, what are you remember?’
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.3.14_0: ‘When I was a young, I sat on the ground and ate the top shoots of the banyan tree.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.3.15_0: These are the traditions of the ancient.’
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.3.16_0: The monkey and the elephant asked the partridge,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.3.17_0: ‘Well, my friend, what are you remember?’
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.3.18_0: ‘In such and such a spot there was a great banyan tree.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.3.19_0: I ate one of its fruits and defecated here.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.3.20_0: This banyan tree has grown from that.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.3.21_0: Well then, I must be the oldest one.’
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.3.22_0: The monkey and the elephant said to the partridge,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.3.24_0: We will honor, respect, and esteem you, and we’ll wait for your instructions.’
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.3.25_0: The partridge had the monkey and the elephant take the five precepts, and he also undertook them himself.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.3.26_0: They were respectful, deferential, and courteous toward one another. And when they died, they were reborn in a happy, heavenly destination.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.3.27_0: In this way the spiritual life called _tittiriya_ came to be.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.3.29_0: And who are learned in the Teaching,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.3.30_0: They are praised while still alive,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.3.31_0: And then go to a good destination.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.4.1_0: “Even those animals, monks, were respectful, deferential, and courteous toward one another.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.4.2_0: Having gone forth on this well-proclaimed spiritual path, will you look good if you are disrespectful, undeferential, and rude toward one another?
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.4.3_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...” ...
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.4.5_0: and after giving a teaching he addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.4.6_0: “You should do these things according to seniority: bowing down, standing up, raising your joined palms, doing acts of respect, giving the best seat, giving the best water, and giving the best almsfood.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.4.7_0: But what belongs to the Sangha should not be reserved according to seniority.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.4.8_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.5.0_0: Persons one should not pay respect to, etc.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.5.1_0: “Monks, you should not pay respect to these ten kinds of persons:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.5.2_0: one who has been given the full ordination after you; one who isn’t fully ordained; one who belongs to a different Buddhist sect who is senior to you, but who speaks contrary to the Teaching; a woman; a _paṇḍaka_; one who is on probation; one who deserves to be sent back to the beginning; one who deserves to be given the trial period; one who is undertaking the trial period; or one who deserves rehabilitation.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.5.3_0: These are the ten kinds of persons.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.5.4_0: You should pay respect to these three kinds of persons:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.5.5_0: one who has been given the full ordination before you; one who belongs to a different Buddhist sect who is senior to you and who speaks in accordance with the Teaching; and in this world with its gods, its lords of death, and its supreme beings, in this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans, you should pay respect to the Buddha, perfected and fully awakened.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:6.5.6_0: These are the three kinds of persons.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:7.1_0: At that time people prepared roof-covers, mats, and places to stay for the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:7.2_0: The monks who were the pupils of the monks from the group of six, thought,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:7.3_0: “The Buddha has instructed that what belongs to the Sangha should not be reserved according to seniority. But he has given no such instruction about what has merely been prepared for the Sangha.” They then went ahead of the Sangha headed by the Buddha and took possession of roof-covers, mats, and places to stay, thinking,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:7.4_0: “This is our preceptor; this will be our preceptor for our teacher.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:7.5_0: Venerable Sāriputta followed behind the Sangha. Being unable to get a bed—the dwellings and beds having all been taken—he sat down at the foot of a tree.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:7.6_0: Then, after rising early in the morning, the Buddha cleared his throat.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:7.7_0: Sāriputta also gave him his throat.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:7.12_0: Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:7.13_0: “Is it true, monks, that the monks who are the pupils of the monks from the group of six did this?”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:7.14_0: ‘The Buddha has instructed that what belongs to the Sangha should not be reserved according to seniority. But he has given no such instruction about what has merely been prepared for the Sangha.’ They then went ahead of the Sangha headed by the Buddha and took possession of roof-covers, mats, and places to stay, thinking,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:7.15_0: This will be your preceptor for our teachers. This will be yours?”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:7.18_0: and after giving a teaching he addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:7.19_0: “Even what has merely been prepared for the Sangha should not be reserved according to seniority.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:7.20_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:8.0_0: The allowance for what belongs to a householder
ai-pli-tv-kd16:8.1_0: At that time people prepared high and luxurious resting places in the dining halls in inhabited areas, that is:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:8.2_0: a high couch, a luxurious couch, a long-fleeced woolen rug, a multi-colored woolen rug, a white woolen rug, a red woolen rug, a cotton-down quilt, a woolen rug decorated with the images of predatory animals, a woolen rug with long fleece on one side, a woolen rug with long fleece on both sides, a sheet of silk embroidered with gems, a silken sheet, a woolen rug like a dancers’ rug, an elephant-back rug, a horse-back rug, a carriage-seat rug, a rug made of black antelope hide, an excellent rug made of _kadalī_-deer hide, a seat with a canopy, a seat with red cushions at each end.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:8.3_0: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not sit down.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:8.4_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:8.6_0: the high couch, the luxurious couch, and the cotton-down quilt,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:8.7_0: It’s not possible for a householder to sit down on it.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:8.8_0: At that time people prepared beds and benches upholstered with cotton down in the dining halls in inhabited areas.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:8.9_0: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not sit down.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:8.10_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:8.11_0: “I allow you to sit down on what belongs to a householder, but not to lie down on it.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:9.0_0: The expression of appreciation for the Jeta Grove dwellings
ai-pli-tv-kd16:9.1.1_0: Wandering on, the Buddha eventually arrived at Sāvatthī,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:9.1.2_0: where he stayed in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Park.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:9.1.3_0: Anāthapiṇḍika then went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:9.1.5_0: “Venerable Sir, please accept tomorrow’s meal from me together with the Sangha of monks.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:9.1.6_0: And the Buddha consented by remaining silent.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:9.1.7_0: Knowing that the Buddha had consented, Anāthapiṇḍika got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:9.1.8_0: The following morning Anāthapiṇḍika had various kinds of fine food prepared. He then had the Buddha informed
ai-pli-tv-kd16:9.1.9_0: “Sir, it’s time. The meal is ready.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:9.1.10_0: The Buddha robed up, took his bowl and robe, and went to Anāthapiṇḍika’s house, where he sat down on the prepared seat together with the Sangha of monks.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:9.1.11_0: Anāthapiṇḍika then personally served the various kinds of fine food to the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha. When the Buddha had finished his meal and had washed his hands and bowl, Anāthapiṇḍika sat down to one side
ai-pli-tv-kd16:9.1.13_0: “Sir, what should I do in regard to the Jeta Grove?”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:9.1.14_0: “You should dedicate the Jeta Grove to the Sangha everywhere, present and future.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:9.2.1_0: The Buddha then expressed his appreciation with these verses:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:9.2.6_0: It keeps away the burning wind,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:9.2.8_0: Covered for the pride, and for the sake of pleasure,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:9.2.9_0: To attain absorption and to see clearly.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:9.2.11_0: the best of Buddhas is praised by the Buddha;
ai-pli-tv-kd16:9.2.12_0: Therefore the astute person is astute
ai-pli-tv-kd16:9.2.13_0: out of regard for my own welfare.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:9.2.15_0: and settle learned people in them.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:9.2.18_0: should be given to the upright ones,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:9.2.22_0: And understanding this Teaching in this life,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:9.2.24_0: The Buddha then got up from his seat and left.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.1.1_0: On one occasion a certain government official who was an Ājīvaka disciple was offering a meal to the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.1.2_0: Afterwards Upananda returned to the monk,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.1.3_0: I became a rabble of food.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.1.4_0: That government official complained and criticized them,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.1.5_0: “How can the Sakyan ascetics act like this?
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.1.6_0: I became a rabble of food.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.1.7_0: It’s impossible to eat as much as you like when you’re not seated.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.1.8_0: The monks heard the complaints of the official,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.1.9_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Devadatta,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.1.13_0: “Is it true, Upananda, that you acted like this?”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.1.16_0: “Foolish man, how can you act like this?
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.1.17_0: I became a rabble of food.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.1.18_0: Foolish man, this won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.1.20_0: and after giving a teaching he addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.1.21_0: “You should not make the announcement about food.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.1.22_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.1.23_0: If you’re asked to get up, and you have already refused an invitation to eat more, you should say, “Please, go and get some water.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.1.24_0: If the other goes, all is well.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.1.25_0: If not, you should properly swallow the mouthful and give the seat to the more senior monk.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.1.26_0: Under no circumstances should you block a more senior monk from a seat.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.1.27_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.2.1_0: On one occasion the monks from the group of six asked the sick monks to get up.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.2.3_0: “We’re not able to get up; we’re sick.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.2.4_0: Saying, “We’ll make the venerables get up,” they took hold of them, lifted them up, and then released them when they were standing.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.2.5_0: The sick monks fainted and collapsed.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.2.6_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.2.7_0: “You should not make the sick get up.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.2.8_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.2.9_0: When the monks from the group of six knew that
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.2.10_0: “We’re sick and no-one can make us get up.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.2.11_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.2.12_0: “You should give suitable beds to those who are sick.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.2.13_0: The monks from the group of six used a pretext to reserve resting places.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.2.14_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.2.15_0: “You should not use a pretext to reserve a resting place.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:10.2.16_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.1.1_0: At that time the monks from the group of seventeen objected to a certain dwelling,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.1.3_0: When they saw the monks from the group of six,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.1.5_0: and they told them what had happened.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.1.8_0: “Let’s wait until they’ve finished repairing it.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.1.9_0: They said to the monks from the group of six,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.1.10_0: “Get up, reverends, our dwelling is our dwelling.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.1.12_0: We would have repaired another one.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.1.13_0: “Have you not been a dwelling belonging to the Sangha?”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.1.15_0: “Get up, reverends, our dwelling is our dwelling.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.1.17_0: You too should stay control you.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.1.18_0: and told him what had happened.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.1.19_0: The monks from the group of seventeen cried.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.1.20_0: When other monks asked him why,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.1.22_0: and they told them what had happened.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.1.23_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Devadatta,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.1.24_0: “How can the monks from the group of six throw themselves out in anger?”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.1.25_0: They then told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned Devadatta:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.1.26_0: “Is it true, monks, that you did this?”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.1.29_0: and after giving a teaching he addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.1.30_0: “You should not, in anger, throw a monk out of a dwelling belonging to the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.1.31_0: If you do, you should be dealt with according to the rule.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.2.0_0: The appointment of allocators of dwellings
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.2.3_0: They told the Buddha. He then had the Sangha gathered and addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.2.4_0: “You should appoint a monk who has five qualities as the allocator of dwellings:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.2.5_0: he is not swayed by desire, ill will, confusion, or fear, and he knows what has and has not been received.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.2.6_0: And you should be approved like this:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.2.7_0: First you should ask a monk, and then a competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.2.8_0: ‘Sir, let the Saṅgha listen to me.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.2.9_0: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, the Sangha should appoint monk so-and-so as allocator of dwellings.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.2.11_0: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.2.12_0: The Sangha appoints monk so-and-so as allocator of dwellings.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.2.13_0: Any monk who approves of appointing monk so-and-so as allocator of dwellings should remain silent.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.2.14_0: Any monk who doesn’t approves should speak up.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.2.15_0: The Sangha has appointed monk so-and-so as allocator of dwellings.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.2.16_0: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.3.3_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.3.4_0: “First you should count the monks and the beds. You should then allocate one monk to each bed.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.3.5_0: When they were allocating the beds, there were beds left over.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.3.6_0: “You should allocate one monk to each dwelling.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.3.7_0: When they were allocating the dwellings, there were dwellings left over.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.3.8_0: “You should allocate one monk to the precincts of each dwelling.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.3.9_0: When they were allocating the precincts, there were precincts left over.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.3.11_0: If another monk arrives after the additional shares have been allocated, then if you’re unwilling, you need not give him a share.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.3.12_0: On one occasion the monks allocated a dwelling to one who was outside the monastic boundary.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.3.13_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.3.14_0: “You should not allocate a dwelling to one outside the monastic boundary.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.3.15_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.3.16_0: At that time, after accepting a dwelling, the monks reserved it at all times.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.3.17_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.3.18_0: “After you have accepted a dwelling, you should not reserve it at all times.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.3.19_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.3.20_0: “Monks, I allow you to reserve three months before the rainy season residence. But not to block a dwelling.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.4.2_0: “How many times are there for the allocation of dwellings?”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.4.3_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.4.4_0: “There are three times for the allocation of dwellings:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.4.5_0: the first, the second, and when given up in between.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.4.6_0: The first allocation is on the day after the full moon of July.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.4.7_0: The last month of the rainy season should be distributed.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.4.8_0: The allocation of what is given up in between the two is on the day after the invitation procedure and is for the purpose of spending the next rains residence.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.4.9_0: These are the three times for the allocation of dwellings.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:11.4.10_0: The second recitation section is finished.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:12.1.1_0: On one occasion Venerable Upananda the Sakyan had accepted a dwelling at Sāvatthī, but then went to a certain village monastery,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:12.1.2_0: where he was also allocated a dwelling.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:12.1.4_0: “This Upananda is quarrelsome and argumentative, and creates legal issues in the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:12.1.5_0: If he spends the rainy season here, none of us will be at ease.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:12.1.8_0: “Have you not been allocated a dwelling at Sāvatthī? ”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:12.1.12_0: and take the one at Sāvatthī.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:12.1.13_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Devadatta,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:12.1.14_0: “How could Upananda reserve two dwellings for himself?”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:12.1.15_0: They told the Buddha. He then had the Sangha gathered and addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:12.1.16_0: “Is it true, Upananda, that you did this?”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:12.1.19_0: “Foolish man, how can you reserve two dwellings for yourself?
ai-pli-tv-kd16:12.1.20_0: What you had been allocated at Sāvatthī, you gave up when you were allocated a dwelling here. And what you have been allocated here, you have now given up.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:12.1.22_0: Foolish man, this won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...
ai-pli-tv-kd16:12.1.24_0: and after giving a teaching he addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:12.1.25_0: “A single monk should not reserve two dwellings.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:12.1.26_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:13.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha gave many talks about the Monastic Law, spoke in praise of the Monastic Law and of learning the Monastic Law, and he repeatedly praised Venerable Upāli.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:13.1.4_0: “Well then, let’s learn the Monastic Law from Venerable Upāli.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:13.1.5_0: And many monks, both senior and junior, as well as those of middle standing, learned the Monastic Law from Upāli.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:13.1.6_0: Out of respect for the senior monks, Upāli taught while standing.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:13.1.7_0: And out of respect for the Teaching, the senior monks, too, were standing.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:13.1.8_0: Both the senior monks and Upāli became tired.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:13.1.9_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:13.1.10_0: “A junior monk who is teaching should sit on a similar or higher seat out of respect for the Teaching.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:13.1.11_0: A senior monk who is being taught should sit on a similar or lower seat out of respect for the Teaching.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:13.2.1_0: On one occasion many monks were standing in the presence of Upāli, honoring the recitation. They became tired.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:13.2.2_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:13.2.3_0: “I allow those who are entitled to a seat of the same height to sit together.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:13.2.5_0: “Who are entitled to a seat of the same height?”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:13.2.7_0: “I allow those with a difference of three years or less in seniority to sit together.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:13.2.8_0: On one occasion a number of monks entitled to a seat of the same height were seated on a bed; the bed broke. They were seated on the same bench; the bench broke.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:13.2.9_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:13.2.10_0: “I allow a maximum of three on a bed or bench.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:13.2.11_0: The beds and benches still broke.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:13.2.12_0: “I allow a maximum of two on a bed or bench.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:13.2.13_0: At that time, being afraid of wrongdoing, monks who were not entitled to a seat of the same height did not sit together on a long seat.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:13.2.14_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:13.2.15_0: “I allow those who are not entitled to a seat of the same height to sit together on a long seat, except with a _paṇḍaka_, a woman, or a hermaphrodite.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:13.2.17_0: “What is the size of the smallest long seat?”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:13.2.18_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:13.2.19_0: “A seat for three is the smallest long seat.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:14.1.1_0: At one time Visākhā Migāramātā wanted to build a stilt house for the benefit of the Sangha, including a porch and elephant globes.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:14.1.3_0: “What stilt-house equipment has the Buddha allowed and what has he not allowed?”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:14.1.4_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:14.1.6_0: At one time King Pasenadi of Kosala’s grandmother had just died.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:14.1.7_0: As a result, many unallowable goods were given to the Sangha, that is:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:14.1.8_0: a high couch, a luxurious couch, a long-fleeced woolen rug, a multi-colored woolen rug, a white woolen rug, a red woolen rug, a cotton-down quilt, a woolen rug decorated with the images of predatory animals, a woolen rug with long fleece on one side, a woolen rug with long fleece on both side, a sheet of silk embroidered with gems, a silken sheet, a woolen rug like a dancers’ rug, an elephant-back rug, a horse-back rug, a carriage-seat rug, a rug made of black antelope hide, an excellent rug made of _kadalī_-deer hide, a seat or bed with a canopy, a seat or bed with red cushions at each end.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:14.1.9_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:14.1.10_0: “I allow you to use a high couch after cutting its legs down to size, to use a luxurious couch after removing the images of predatory animals, to make a pillow after removing the cotton down from the cotton-down quilt, and to make floor covers of the rest.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.1.0_0: What is not to be given away
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.1.1_0: At one time in a village monastery not far from Sāvatthī the resident monks were fed up with assigning dwellings for newly arrived and departing monks.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.1.3_0: “Reverend Upavāna, while the newly arrived monks are assigning dwellings for newly arrived monks.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.1.4_0: and thought, “Well, let’s give all the dwellings belonging to the Sangha to one of us.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.1.5_0: We’ll then use what belongs to him.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.1.7_0: When newly arrived monks said to them,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.1.9_0: they replied, “There are no dwellings belonging to the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.1.10_0: They have all been given to one of us.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.1.11_0: “So you have given away the dwellings belonging to the Sangha?”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.1.13_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Devadatta,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.1.14_0: “How can monks give away dwellings belonging to the Sangha?”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.1.15_0: They then told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned Devadatta:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.1.16_0: “Is it true, monks, that they did this?”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.1.19_0: “How can those foolish men give away dwellings belonging to the Sangha?
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.1.20_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...” ...
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.1.22_0: and after giving a teaching he addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.2.1_0: “There are five things not to be given away, either by a sangha, a group, or an individual.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.2.2_0: When they have been given away,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.2.3_0: If you give any of them away, you commit a serious offense.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.2.5_0: A monastery or the site of a monastery;
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.2.6_0: I have given away first to be given away, either by a sangha, a group, or an individual.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.2.7_0: it has not been given away.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.2.8_0: If you give any of them away, you commit a serious offense.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.2.9_0: A dwelling or the site of a dwelling;
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.2.10_0: This is the second thing, but not to be given away, either by a sangha, a group, or an individual.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.2.11_0: it has not been given away.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.2.12_0: If you give any of them away, you commit a serious offense.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.2.13_0: The beds and benches, the mattress covers, and the pillow.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.2.14_0: This is the third thing, but not to be given away, either by a sangha, a group, or an individual.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.2.15_0: it has not been given away.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.2.16_0: If you give any of them away, you commit a serious offense.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.2.17_0: A metal pot, a metal jar, a metal bucket, a metal bowl, a adz, a hatchet, an ax, a spade, or a chisel;
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.2.18_0: This is the fourth thing, but not to be given away, either by a sangha, a group, or an individual.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.2.19_0: it has not been given away.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.2.20_0: If you give any of them away, you commit a serious offense.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.2.21_0: A creeper, bamboo, reed, grass, clay, wooden goods, or ceramic goods.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.2.22_0: This is the fifth thing, which should not be given away, either by a sangha, a group, or an individual.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.2.23_0: it has not been given away.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.2.24_0: If you give any of them away, you commit a serious offense.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.2.25_0: These are the five things not to be given away, either by a sangha, a group, or an individual.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.2.26_0: When they have been given away,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:15.2.27_0: If you give any of them away, you commit a serious offense.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.1.0_0: What is not to be shared out
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.1.1_0: When the Buddha had stayed at Sāvatthī for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Kīṭāgiri with a large sangha of five hundred monks, including Sāriputta and Mahāmoggallāna.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.1.2_0: The monks Assaji and Punabbasuka heard about this and said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.1.3_0: “The Buddha is coming with a large sangha of five hundred monks, including Sāriputta and Mahāmoggallāna.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.1.4_0: “Well, let’s share out all the dwellings belonging to the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.1.5_0: Sāriputta and Mahāmoggallāna are in the grip of bad desires.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.1.6_0: We won’t assign dwellings to them.” And they shared out all the dwellings belonging to the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.1.7_0: The Buddha eventually arrived at Kīṭāgiri.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.1.8_0: And he said to a group of monks,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.1.10_0: “Go to the monks Assaji and Punabbasuka and say,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.1.11_0: ‘The Buddha is coming with a large sangha of five hundred monks, including Sāriputta and Mahāmoggallāna.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.1.12_0: Assign dwellings to the Buddha, to the Sangha of monks, and to Sāriputta and Mahāmoggallāna.’”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.1.13_0: Saying, “Yes, Sir,” they did just that.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.1.14_0: “The Buddha is coming with a large sangha of five hundred monks, including Sāriputta and Mahāmoggallāna.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.1.15_0: Assign dwellings to the Buddha, to the Sangha of monks, and to Sāriputta and Mahāmoggallāna.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.1.16_0: The monks Assaji and Punabbasuka replied, “There are no dwellings belonging to the Sangha;
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.1.17_0: they have all been shared out by us.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.1.19_0: and he may stay wherever he likes.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.1.20_0: But Sāriputta and Mahāmoggallāna are in the grip of bad desires.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.1.21_0: We won’t assign dwellings to them.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.1_0: “So you have shared out the dwellings belonging to the Sangha?”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.3_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Devadatta,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.4_0: “How can these monks share out dwellings belonging to the Sangha?”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.5_0: They then told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned Devadatta:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.9_0: “How can those foolish men share out the dwellings belonging to the Sangha?
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.10_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...” ...
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.12_0: and after giving a teaching he addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.13_0: “There are five things not to be shared out, either by a sangha, a group, or an individual.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.14_0: They eat in one part of the day.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.15_0: If you share out any of them, you commit a serious offense.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.17_0: A monastery or the site of a monastery;
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.18_0: This is the first thing, which should not be shared out, either by a sangha, a group, or an individual.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.19_0: They eat in one part of the day.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.20_0: If you share out any of them, you commit a serious offense.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.21_0: A dwelling or the site of a dwelling;
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.22_0: This is the second thing, which should not be shared out, either by a sangha, a group, or an individual.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.23_0: They eat in one part of the day.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.24_0: If you share out any of them, you commit a serious offense.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.25_0: The beds and benches, the mattress covers, and the pillow.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.26_0: This is the third thing, which should not be shared out, either by a sangha, a group, or an individual.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.27_0: They eat in one part of the day.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.28_0: If you share out any of them, you commit a serious offense.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.29_0: A metal pot, a metal jar, a metal bucket, a metal bowl, a adz, a hatchet, an ax, a spade, or a chisel;
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.30_0: This is the fourth thing, but not to be shared out, either by a sangha, a group, or an individual.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.31_0: They eat in one part of the day.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.32_0: If you share out any of them, you commit a serious offense.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.33_0: A creeper, bamboo, reed, grass, clay, wooden goods, or ceramic goods.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.34_0: This is the fifth thing, which should not be shared out, either by a sangha, a group, or an individual.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.35_0: They eat in one part of the day.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.36_0: If you share out any of them, you commit a serious offense.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.37_0: These are the five things not to be shared out, either by a sangha, a group, or an individual.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.38_0: They eat in one part of the day.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:16.2.39_0: If you share out any of them, you commit a serious offense.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.0_0: Discussion on putting in charge of building work
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.1_0: When the Buddha had stayed at Kīṭāgiri for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Āḷavī.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.3_0: he too stayed at the Aggāḷava Shrine.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.4_0: At that time the monks of Āḷava put monks in charge of building work such as this:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.8_0: the mere making of bolt-receiving posts,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.10_0: the mere application of white coloring,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.11_0: the mere application of black coloring,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.12_0: the mere treatment with red ocher,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.13_0: the mere covering with a roof,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.14_0: the mere fastening of a roof,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.16_0: the mere repair of what is defective or broken,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.17_0: the mere plastering of a floor;
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.18_0: and they put monks in charge of building work for twenty years,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.20_0: they put monks in charge of building work for life.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.21_0: and they put monks in charge of building work for life on finished dwellings.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.22_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Devadatta,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.23_0: “How can the monks at Āḷavī put monks in charge of such kinds of work?”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.35_0: mere repair of what is defective or broken,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.39_0: they live as long as they live ...
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.40_0: and they put monks in charge of building work for life on finished dwellings.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.41_0: They told the Buddha. He then had the Sangha gathered and addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.45_0: and after giving a teaching he addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.46_0: “You should not put monks in charge of building work such as this: the mere filling of gaps,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.49_0: the mere making of bolt-receiving posts,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.51_0: the mere application of white coloring,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.52_0: the mere application of black coloring,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.53_0: the mere treatment with red ocher,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.54_0: the mere covering with a roof,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.55_0: the mere fastening of a roof,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.57_0: the mere repair of what is defective or broken,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.58_0: or the mere plastering of a floor;
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.59_0: and you should not put monks in charge of building work for twenty years,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.61_0: put monks in charge of building work.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.62_0: or put monks in charge of building work for life on finished dwellings.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.63_0: If he does, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.1.64_0: I allow you to put in charge of building work for six months in a dwelling, in a small dwelling, or to build a dwelling, and torch a sunshade in charge; with building work.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.2.1_0: On one occasion the monks put one person in charge of building work on all the dwellings.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.2.2_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.2.3_0: “You should not put one person in charge of building work on all the dwellings.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.2.4_0: If he does, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.2.5_0: On one occasion the monks put one person in charge of building work on two dwellings.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.2.6_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.2.7_0: “You should not put one person in charge of building work on two dwellings.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.2.8_0: If he does, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.2.9_0: On one occasion the monks who had taken on building work had someone else stay in the dwelling.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.2.10_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.2.11_0: “When you have taken on building work, you should not have someone else stay in that dwelling.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.2.12_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.2.13_0: At one time monks who had taken on building work reserved what belonged to the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.2.14_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.2.15_0: “When you have taken on building work, you should not reserve what belongs to the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.2.16_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.2.17_0: I allow you to take one good bed.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.2.18_0: On one occasion the monks put one who was outside the monastic boundary in charge of building work.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.2.19_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.2.20_0: “You should not put one who is outside the monastic boundary in charge of building work.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.2.21_0: If he does, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.2.22_0: At one time the monks who had taken on building work reserved a dwelling at all times.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.2.23_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.2.24_0: “When you have taken on building work, you should not reserve a dwelling at all times.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.2.25_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.2.26_0: “Monks, I allow you to reserve three months before the rainy season residence. But not to block a dwelling.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.3.1_0: At that time monks who had taken on building work left, disrobed, died,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.3.3_0: admitted to having renounced the training,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.3.4_0: admitted to having committed the worst kind of offense,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.3.7_0: admitted to being overwhelmed by pain,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.3.8_0: admitted to having been suspended for not recognizing an offense,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.3.9_0: admitted to having been suspended for not making amends for an offense,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.3.10_0: admitted to having been suspended for not giving up a bad view,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.3.12_0: admitted to be living in the community by theft,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.3.13_0: admitted to previously having left to join the ascetics of another religion,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.3.17_0: admitted to being a murderer of a perfected one,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.3.18_0: admitted to having raped a nun,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.3.19_0: admitted to having caused a schism in the Sangha,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.3.20_0: admitted to having caused the Buddha to bleed,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.3.22_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.3.23_0: “If a monk who has taken on building work departs,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.3.24_0: he should give it to another Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.3.25_0: If a monk who has taken on building work disrobes,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.3.26_0: dies, admits to being novice monks, admits to having renounced the training, admits to having committed the worst kind of offense, admits to being insane, admits to being deranged, admits to being overwhelmed by pain, admits to having been suspended for not recognizing an offense, admits to having been suspended for not making amends for an offense, admits to having been suspended for not giving up a bad view, admits to being a _paṇḍaka_, admits to be living in the community by theft, admits to previously having left to join the ascetics of another religion, admits to being an animal, admits to being a matricide, admits to being a patricide, admits to being a murderer of a perfected one, admits to having raped a nun, admits to having caused a schism in the Sangha, admits to having caused the Buddha to bleed, or admits to being a hermaphrodite,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.3.27_0: he should give it to another Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.3.28_0: If a monk who has taken on building work departs while it is still unfinished,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.3.29_0: he should give it to another Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.3.30_0: If a monk who has taken on building work disrobes while it is still unfinished ...
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.3.31_0: admits to being a hermaphrodite while it is still unfinished,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.3.32_0: he should give it to another Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.3.33_0: If a monk who has taken on building work departs when it is finished,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.3.35_0: If a monk who has taken on building work disrobes when it is finished;
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.3.36_0: dies when it is finished; admits, when it is finished, to being a novice monk; admits, when it is finished, to having renounced the training; or admits, when it is finished, to having committed the worst kind of offense,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.3.37_0: then the Sangha is the owner.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.3.38_0: If a monk who has taken on building work admits, when it is finished, to being insane; admits, when it is finished, to being deranged; admits, when it is finished, to being overwhelmed by pain; admits, when it is finished, to having been suspended for not recognizing an offense; admits, when it is finished, to having been suspended for not making amends for an offense; or admits, when it is finished, to having been suspended for not giving up a bad view,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.3.40_0: If a monk who has taken on building work admits, when it is finished, to being a _paṇḍaka_; admits, when it is finished, to be living in the community by theft; admits, when it is finished, to previously having left to join the ascetics of another religion; admits, when it is finished, to being an animal; admits, when it is finished, to being a matricide; admits, when it is finished, to being a patricide; admits, when it is finished, to being a murderer of a perfected one; admits, when it is finished, to having raped a nun; admits, when it is finished, to having caused a schism in the Sangha; admits, when it is finished, to having caused the Buddha to bleed; or admits, when it is finished, to being a hermaphrodite,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:17.3.41_0: then the Sangha is the owner.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:18.1.0_0: The prohibition against using requisites elsewhere, etc.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:18.1.1_0: On one occasion a lay follower used furniture to use it except if the monks had agreed.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:18.1.2_0: Then that lay follower complained and criticized him,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:18.1.3_0: “How can those Venerables use furniture where it doesn’t belong?”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:18.1.4_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:18.1.5_0: “You should not use the furniture where it doesn’t belong to.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:18.1.6_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:18.1.7_0: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not take any equipment to the observance-day hall or to meetings, and they sat down on the bare ground.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:18.1.8_0: Their limbs and robes became dirty.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:18.1.9_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:18.1.11_0: At that time a large dwelling belonging to the Sangha was decaying.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:18.1.12_0: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not remove the furniture.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:18.1.13_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:18.1.14_0: “I allow you to move it for the purpose of protection.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:19.1.1_0: At that time the Sangha was given a valuable furniture cloth.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:19.1.2_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:19.1.3_0: “I allow you to swap it for the purpose of protecting.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:19.1.4_0: On one occasion the Sangha was given a valuable furniture cloth.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:19.1.5_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:19.1.6_0: “I allow you to swap it for the purpose of protecting.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:19.1.7_0: On one occasion the Sangha was given a bear skin.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:19.1.8_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:19.1.9_0: “I allow you to make a foot-wife.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:19.1.10_0: On one occasion the Sangha was given a round pad.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:19.1.11_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:19.1.12_0: “I allow you to make a foot-wife.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:19.1.13_0: On one occasion the Sangha was given a cloth.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:19.1.14_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:19.1.15_0: “I allow you to make a foot-wife.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:20.1.1_0: At that time the monks entered the dwellings with dirty feet.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:20.1.3_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:20.1.4_0: “You should not enter a dwelling with dirty feet.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:20.1.5_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:20.1.6_0: At that time the monks entered the dwellings with wet feet.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:20.1.8_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:20.1.9_0: “You should not enter a dwelling with wet feet.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:20.1.10_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:20.1.11_0: At that time the monks entered the dwellings with their sandals on.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:20.1.13_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:20.1.14_0: “You should not enter a dwelling with your sandals on.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:20.1.15_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:20.2.1_0: At that time the monks spat on treated floors.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:20.2.3_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:20.2.4_0: “You should not spit on treated floors.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:20.2.5_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:20.2.7_0: At that time the legs of the beds and benches scratched the treated floors. The coloring was spoiled.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:20.2.8_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:20.2.9_0: “You should wrap the legs in cloth.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:20.2.10_0: At that time the monks were leaning on treated walls.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:20.2.12_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:20.2.13_0: “You should not lean on treated walls.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:20.2.14_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:20.2.16_0: The lower edge of the leaning boards scratched the floor and the upper edge the wall.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:20.2.17_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:20.2.18_0: “You should wrap the lower and upper edges in cloth.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:20.2.19_0: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not lie down with washed feet.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:20.2.20_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:20.2.21_0: “You should spread a sheet and then lie down.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.1.0_0: The allowance for meals for the Sangha, etc.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.1.1_0: When the Buddha had stayed at Āḷavī for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Rājagaha.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.1.2_0: When he eventually arrived at Rājagaha,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.1.3_0: When he eventually arrived, he stayed in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrel sanctuary.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.1.4_0: At that time Rājagaha was short of food
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.1.5_0: and people were not able to make meals for the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.1.6_0: Instead they wished to make meals for designated monks, invitational meals, meals for which lots are drawn, half-monthly meals, meals on the observance day, and meals on the day after the observance day.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.1.7_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.1.8_0: “I allow meals for the Sangha, meals for designated monks, invitational meals, meals for which lots are drawn, half-monthly meals, meals on the observance days, and meals on the days after the observance day.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.1.9.0_0: The appointment of a designator of meals
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.1.9.1_0: At that time the monks from the group of six took the best meals for themselves and gave the inferior ones to the other monks.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.1.10_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.1.11_0: “You should appoint a monk who has five qualities as the designator of meals:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.1.12_0: he is not swayed by desire, ill will, confusion, or fear, and he knows what has and has not been designated.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.1.13_0: And this is how it should be designated.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.1.14_0: First you should ask a monk, and then a competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.1.15_0: ‘Sir, let the Saṅgha listen to me.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.1.16_0: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, the Sangha should appoint monk so-and-so as designator of meals.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.1.18_0: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.1.19_0: The Sangha appoints monk so-and-so as designator of meals.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.1.20_0: Any monk who approves of appointing monk so-and-so as designator of meals should remain silent.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.1.21_0: Any monk who doesn’t approves should speak up.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.1.22_0: The Sangha has appointed monk so-and-so as designator of meals.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.1.23_0: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.1.24_0: The monks who were designator of meals thought,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.1.26_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.1.27_0: “You should mark the tickets and make a heap of them, and then designate the meals.”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.2.0_0: The appointment of assigners of dwellings, etc.

ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.2.8_0: Because it was not distributed, the non-staple food perished.

ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.2.12_0: And this is how it should be designated.

ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.2.15_0: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, the Sangha should appoint monk so-and-so as distributor of non-staple food.

ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.2.18_0: The Sangha appoints monk so-and-so as distributor of non-staple food.

ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.2.20_0: Any monk who doesn’t approves should speak up.

ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.3.5_0: And this is how it should be designated.

ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.3.14_0: The Sangha has appointed monk so-and-so as distributor of minor requisites.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.3.15_0: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’”
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.3.16_0: The monk who is the distributor of minor requisites should give out, one by one: needles, knives, sandals, belts, shoulder straps, water filters, water strainers; and robe material for long inter-panel strips, short inter-panel strips, large panels, medium-sized panels, lengthwise borders, and crosswise borders.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.3.17_0: If the Sangha has ghee, oil, honey, or syrup, he should give it out for a single use.

ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.3.185_0: The Sakyans were not able to make them,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.3.189_0: The recipient keeps as a urgent,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.3.195_0: A novice disciple of monastery worker
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.3.197_0: He has conquered all and knows the world,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.3.198_0: The Leader intent on what’s beneficial:
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.3.199_0: Covered for the pride, and for the sake of pleasure,
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.3.200_0: To attain absorption and to see clearly.
ai-pli-tv-kd16:21.3.201_0: The chapter on dwellings is finished.
